Award.AwardTitle: URM: Biology Undergraduate Mentoring Program: BUMP into Research at CMU!
Award.AbstractNarration: An award has been made to Central Michigan University (CMU) Department of Biology to establish an Undergraduate Research and Mentoring (URM) program, titled Biology Undergraduate Mentoring Program (BUMP). A cohort of five students will be recruited in each of the first three years of the grant. Over a four-year grant period, a total of 15 students will be trained in the program. BUMP is designed to develop a community of undergraduates from historically underrepresented groups and engage these students in high-quality research projects directly mentored by faculty. Students will begin the program in the summer after their freshman or sophomore year, and will be supported for two calendar years. BUMP will form partnerships with urban Michigan high schools and with the local two-year Saginaw Chippewa Tribal College to recruit students from primarily two underrepresented minority groups: African-Americans and Native Americans. Students selected for BUMP will be assigned three mentors: a Faculty Mentor who will act as their academic advisor, a Peer Mentor, and a Research Mentor. At least twenty-seven faculty within the Department of Biology have agreed to serve as potential Research Mentors, and these faculty members are dedicated to both teaching and research. BUMP students will have a broad array of biological research areas to choose from and will be encouraged to tailor their research pursuits to an area that fits their individual interests. Areas of potential research range from cellular and molecular biology to ecology, evolution, and conservation biology. In addition to the research experiences, students will take seminar courses to introduce them to careers in biological research, to develop skills in experimental design, to develop scientific communication skills, to prepare for the GRE, and to successfully apply to graduate school. For more information, contact Dr. Cynthia Damer at damer1ck@cmich.edu or Dr. Anna Monfils at monfi1ak@cmich.edu, or visit http://BUMPResearch.bio.cmich.edu.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Central Michigan University was awarded funds by the NSF to create an undergraduate research opportunity titled the Biology Undergraduate Mentoring Program (BUMP).  The goal of BUMP was to increase the diversity of individuals pursuing graduate studies in biological research. BUMP recruited students from historically underrepresented groups, engaged these students in high-quality research projects mentored by our faculty, and developed a program to prepare them for graduate school. Students began the program in their first or second year at CMU and received two years of support. BUMP recruited four cohorts of ~ five students. Students in the program took three courses: a pathways to research course to help them navigate their undergraduate experience in preparation for a career in biological research, a scientific communication course to develop their writing, speaking and presentation skills, and a GRE preparation course.  BUMP students were supported by collaborations between the Biology Department, the Multicultural Education Center, GEAR-UP, and the McNair Program. Participants volunteered at the Chippewa Nature Center and at local middle schools. The program was assessed throughout to determine the impacts and efficacy of individual program components and to look at the outcomes of the program overall. Although recruitment and retention were challenges, the program was highly successful for students who completed the program.  Of the eleven students who completed the two year program, one student completed a masters degree, two are currently in masters programs, two are currently in PhD programs, one is currently in veterinary school, and three are currently still at CMU and plan to apply to graduate schools.  Therefore, nine out of the eleven students are either in graduate school (one in vet school) or planning to apply to graduate school.  Survey and interview data showed that participants in the program had a significant increase in self-efficacy, a clear perspective on career opportunities, and a realistic plan for their career pathway into biological research.
